qas.question: When did Britain formally surrender sovreignty over Hong Kong?
When Hong Kong was a colony of Great Britain, which body was the highest court of appeal?

answers.text: the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council (JCPC)

qas.question: When was the Court of Final Appeal established?
The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress is seated in what city?
What event occurred in Hong Kong in 1979?

plausible_answers.text: Judicial Committee of the Privy Council

qas.question: What is also known as the CJPC?

plausible_answers.text: judges from other common law jurisdictions (including England and Wales) can be recruited and continue to serve in the judiciary

qas.question: What does Article 29 of the Basic Law state?

plausible_answers.text: the courts are authorised to interpret the Basic Law when trying cases

qas.question: What does Article 185 of the Basic Law state?

context: In Hong Kong, the Supreme Court of Hong Kong (now known as the High Court of Hong Kong) was the final court of appeal during its colonial times which ended with <b5_0>transfer of sovereignty<b5_0/> in <a0_0>1997<a0_0/>. The final adjudication power, as in any other British Colonies, rested with <a1_0>the <b6_0>Judicial Committee of the Privy Council<b6_0/> (JCPC)<a1_0/> in <a2_0>London, United Kingdom<a2_0/>. Now the power of final adjudication is vested in the <b7_0>Court of Final Appeal<b7_0/> created in <a3_0>1997<a3_0/>. Under the Basic Law, its constitution, the territory remains a common law jurisdiction. Consequently, <b8_0>judges from other common law jurisdictions (including England and Wales) can be recruited and continue to serve in the judiciary<b8_0/> according to Article 92 of the Basic Law. On the other hand, the power of interpretation of the Basic Law itself is vested in the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPCSC) in <a4_0>Beijing<a4_0/> (without retroactive effect), and <b9_0>the courts are authorised to interpret the Basic Law when trying cases<b9_0/>, in accordance with Article 158 of the Basic Law. This arrangement became controversial in light of the right of abode issue in 1999, raising concerns for judicial independence.
